Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrated Studies of Continental Triple Junction Tectonics, Northern Central America
Award.AbstractNarration:
A research team from University of Wisconsin and California State University Stanislaus, in collaboration with scientists from El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, France, Mexico, and Spain are carrying out an integrated study of faulting and the earthquake cycle in northern Central America, at the deforming western end of the Caribbean plate. The major emphasis is to better measure and model deformation around a continental triple junction in southern Guatemala, where the Motagua and Polochic fault system terminates the Caribbean-North America plate boundary. Existing and new data from 110 campaign and continuous GPS sites in El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and southern Mexico will be compiled and analyzed to create the first consistent regional-scale GPS velocity field for the western Caribbean. The new velocity field will be used to study four important topics, including: 1) how deformation is accommodated around the continental triple junction; 2) the motion and internal deformation of the Central America forearc sliver; 3) the manner in which the Jalpatagua fault and other volcanic arc faults in Guatemala accommodate this movement and interact with the magmatic arc; and 4) how extension is accommodated between the sinistral Motagua-Polochic fault system and the dextral Jalpatagua fault and the influence on subduction coupling and upper plate deformation of a 50 degree change in the dip of the subducting Cocos plate. Complementary outcrop, gravity, paleomagnetic, radiometric, and geochemical data will be collected in Guatemala and Honduras to provide a geological framework for interpreting and modeling the GPS velocity field. Forward and inverse modeling that integrates the available geodetic and structural observations and suitable earthquake constraints will be used to better understand the factors that dictate deformation in the region and optimize estimates of block rotations, fault coupling and locking depths, and strain rates and directions within quasi-rigid blocks.

Estimates of interseismic strain rates and long-term fault slip rates that will result from this work will inform risk analysis in El Salvador, Honduras, and Guatemala, where destructive earthquakes have occurred in the past 35 years. The study complements publicly funded studies of natural hazards in neighboring countries (i.e. Mexico, Nicaragua, Costa Rica) and together will substantially advance understanding of these hazards in much of Central America and southern Mexico. Training workshops to be held in Guatemala and El Salvador will target one or more techniques and will constitute a mini-forum for presenting project results and educating students, scientists, and the broader public in the host countries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this six-year-long project was to make and model Global Positioning System (GPS) and a variety of geologic observations in northern Central America and southern Mexico to better understand earthquake hazards, fault slip rates and frictional locking, tectonic block rotations and geometries, and volcanic-fault interactions in this region, where three major continental fault zones interact in a poorly understood manner. Measurements at more than 200 GPS sites spanning the study area from 1999 through 2017 were successfully made, compiled, and processed to create a GPS velocity field of unprecedented detail, as displayed in the associated figure. Modeling of the daily measurements at ~100 continuous GPS sites was used to estimate the decaying aftereffects of large regional earthquakes in 2009 and 2012 and correct GPS station positions for those effects to reveal the steady long-term site motions.  Results from the time-dependent modeling were published by Ellis et al. (2018). Modeling of the long-term GPS site velocities published by Ellis et al. (2019) revealed for the first time the existence of two previously unknown tectonic blocks in Central America, strong locking of and westward-decreasing slip rates along the hazardous Motagua-Polochic Fault of Guatemala, decreasing fault slip rates northwestward along the Central America volcanic arc, a transition from weak to moderate frictional locking of the Middle America trench offshore Guatemala, El Salvador, and Nicaragua, termination of all slip on the Motagua Fault and volcanic arc faults within 30-40 km west of the Guatemala CIty Graben, and numerous other details relevant to an improved understanding of the long-term deformation in this region. Targeted geologic studies of fault(s) along the volcanic arcs of El Salvador and Guatemala revealed how volcanic magmas and faults interact, defined the extent of the poorly known, seismically dangerous Jalpatagua Fault of SE Guatemala, and showed for the first time the existence of rapid crustal extension within and near Guatemala City. International workshops in 2015 and 2016 trained ~40 Honduran, Guatemalan, and Salvadoran students and scientists in GPS field and data analysis methods.  The project funds supported three Ph.D. students, all female, including a talented Guatemalan student who is now a professor at Guatemala's leading national university. Related efforts that were stimulated by the NSF grant included building of novel GPS networks in Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador, which will be used to train students and monitor earthquake hazards and eventually, atmospheric phenomena.
